creator: deweese@apache.org
text:
The default memory partition for java is ridiculously small (something like 64MB).
You will need to increase the max memory size for your document to work.
Try running java with something like:

   java -Xmx1024m -jar batik-rasterizer.jar ...

   That will give java 1024 MB to work with...

creator: josephh@newmediagateway.com
text:
Thank you for the advice and that does help to get the image to actually 
render. The problem is that a typical image of the same size takes about 1 
minute to render. For some reason this particular image takes anywhere from 10-
18 minutes to render. Some property of this particular svg file dramatically 
cripples the performance of batik. Let me know if this is an issue that can be 
worked on or if it is something I need to take a further look into myself. 
Thank you very much for your help.

(In reply to comment #4)
> Some property of this particular svg file dramatically 
> cripples the performance of batik. Let me know if this is an issue that can be

> Thank you very much for your help.

You could try to reduce [1] the testcase to an acceptable size and complexity... ;-)  Finding out which particular SVG element (line? complex path? gradient?) and/or interaction of elements is part of the work flow to raise interest on the issue.  Please consider attaching a very simple example, attaching it to this bug to make sure it doesn't get lost (it's not unusual that external links to test cases break after a few weeks or months). :-)

Hope this helps,
 Helder Magalhães

[1] http://webkit.org/quality/reduction.html
